words.meaning: Refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind.
examples: He is adamant that he is not going to resign.
She was adamant about her decision to leave.

words.meaning: Very skilled or proficient at something.
examples: She is adept at cutting through red tape.
He was an adept negotiator.

words.meaning: Satisfactory or acceptable in quality or quantity.
examples: The facilities are adequate for our needs.
He did not have an adequate understanding of the situation.

words.meaning: To stick fast to (a surface or substance); or to believe in and follow the practices of.
examples: The stamp failed to adhere to the envelope.
All members must adhere to the rules.

words.meaning: Someone who supports a particular party, person, or set of ideas.
examples: He was a staunch adherent of the conservative party.
The movement is gaining new adherents every day.

words.meaning: To make a formal judgment or decision about a problem or disputed matter.
examples: The committee will adjudicate on the case.
He was asked to adjudicate the competition.

words.meaning: A thing added to something else as a supplementary rather than an essential part.
examples: The website is an adjunct to the book.
An adjunct professor is not a full-time member of the faculty.

words.meaning: To warn or reprimand someone firmly.
examples: She admonished him for his bad behavior.
The teacher had to admonish the student for being late.

words.meaning: Past tense of admonish; warned or reprimanded firmly.
examples: The judge admonished the witness for lying.
He was admonished by his parents for skipping school.

words.meaning: Made more beautiful or attractive.
examples: The hall was adorned with flowers and streamers.
She wore a dress adorned with jewels.

words.meaning: Clever or skillful in using the hands or mind.
examples: He was adroit at handling difficult questions.
She is an adroit pianist.

words.meaning: Excessive admiration or praise.
examples: The actor enjoyed the adulation of his fans.
She was the object of public adulation.

words.meaning: To render (something) poorer in quality by adding another substance, typically an inferior one.
examples: It is illegal to adulterate food products.
The wine was adulterated with water.

words.meaning: The arrival of a notable person, thing, or event.
examples: The advent of the internet changed the world.
The advent of spring brings warmer weather.

words.meaning: One's opponent in a contest, conflict, or dispute.
examples: He faced his adversary in the final match.
The two countries were once adversaries in war.

words.meaning: Preventing success or development; harmful; unfavorable.
examples: The drug had adverse side effects.
Adverse weather conditions forced them to cancel the flight.

words.meaning: Difficulties; misfortune.
examples: She showed great courage in the face of adversity.
He overcame many adversities to become successful.

words.meaning: A person who publicly supports or recommends a particular cause or policy.
examples: She is a strong advocate for environmental protection.
He advocates for the rights of the homeless.

words.meaning: The protection, backing, or support of a particular person or organization.
examples: The event was held under the aegis of the local council.
The project is under the aegis of the United Nations.

words.meaning: A large nest of a bird of prey, especially an eagle, typically built high on a tree or cliff.
examples: The eagle returned to its aerie to feed its young.
From our viewpoint, we could see the aerie on the mountaintop.

words.meaning: A person who has or affects to have a special appreciation of art and beauty.
examples: He was a noted aesthete and collector of fine art.
As an aesthete, she was drawn to the beautiful architecture.

words.meaning: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
examples: The new building has a pleasing aesthetic.
His photographs are known for their aesthetic quality.

words.meaning: Friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
examples: He is an affable and approachable manager.
She has a very affable personality.

words.meaning: Behavior, speech, or writing that is artificial and designed to impress.
examples: His accent is just an affectation.
She spoke with an affectation of nonchalance.

words.meaning: Artificial, pretentious, and designed to impress.
examples: He spoke in an affected manner, trying to sound more sophisticated.
Her affected politeness was irritating.

words.meaning: Relating to moods, feelings, and attitudes.
examples: The study focused on the affective responses of the participants.
Affective disorders can impact one's emotional state.

words.meaning: Officially attached or connected to an organization.
examples: The hospital is affiliated with the local university.
They are part of an affiliated group of companies.

words.meaning: A spontaneous or natural liking or sympathy for someone or something.
examples: She has a natural affinity for children.
He felt an immediate affinity with the new colleague.

words.meaning: (of a problem or illness) cause pain or suffering to; affect or trouble.
examples: The country has been afflicted by famine.
Arthritis can afflict people of all ages.

words.meaning: Something that causes pain or suffering.
examples: Poverty is a great affliction in many parts of the world.
He bore his affliction with great courage.

words.meaning: Having a great deal of money; wealthy.
examples: He comes from an affluent family.
They live in an affluent neighborhood.

words.meaning: To have enough money to pay for; or to provide or supply (an opportunity or facility).
examples: I can't afford a new car right now.
The new bridge will afford a quicker route to the city.

words.meaning: An action or remark that causes outrage or offense.
examples: His comments were an affront to the entire community.
She considered his behavior a personal affront.

words.meaning: (of the mouth) wide open, especially with surprise or wonder.
examples: He stared at the scene with his mouth agape.
The children watched the magician, their mouths agape.

words.meaning: The clumping of particles; the process by which red blood cells clump together.
examples: Agglutination of bacteria is a key step in some diagnostic tests.
The test for blood type is based on agglutination.

words.meaning: To increase the power, status, or wealth of.
examples: He used his new position to aggrandize himself.
The dictator sought to aggrandize his empire.

words.meaning: Past tense of aggrandize; increased in power, status, or wealth.
examples: The museum's collection was aggrandized by a generous donation.
His reputation was aggrandized by his recent success.

words.meaning: To make (a problem, injury, or offense) worse or more serious.
examples: His angry response only aggravated the situation.
Running will aggravate your knee injury.

words.meaning: A whole formed by combining several (typically disparate) elements.
examples: The aggregate score of the two games was 5-2.
The company's aggregate profits have increased.

words.meaning: Filled with horror or shock.
examples: She was aghast at the news of the accident.
He stood aghast at the sight of the destruction.

words.meaning: To make (someone) troubled or nervous.
examples: The news seemed to agitate him.
Don't agitate the dog by teasing it.

words.meaning: Very eager or curious to hear or see something.
examples: The children were all agog to see the presents.
We waited agog for the announcement.

words.meaning: Brisk and cheerful readiness.
examples: She accepted the invitation with alacrity.
He responded to the request with alacrity.

words.meaning: Although.
examples: He finally agreed, albeit reluctantly.
It was a good performance, albeit a little long.

words.meaning: The medieval forerunner of chemistry, based on the supposed transformation of matter. It was concerned particularly with attempts to convert base metals into gold or to find a universal elixir.
examples: The ancient practice of alchemy was shrouded in mystery.
He dreamed of discovering the secret of alchemy.

words.meaning: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer.
examples: The search engine uses a complex algorithm to rank websites.
He developed a new algorithm for data compression.

words.meaning: To cause (someone) to feel isolated or estranged.
examples: His sarcastic remarks alienated his friends.
The new policies have alienated many voters.

words.meaning: To diminish or put at rest (fear, suspicion, or worry).
examples: The government's statement did little to allay public fears.
He tried to allay her concerns.

words.meaning: A claim or assertion that someone has done something illegal or wrong, typically one made without proof.
examples: He has denied the allegations against him.
The police are investigating allegations of fraud.

words.meaning: To claim or assert that someone has done something illegal or wrong, typically without proof.
examples: He is alleged to have stolen the money.
The newspaper article alleges that the company is in financial trouble.

words.meaning: (of an incident or a person) said, without proof, to have taken place or to have a specified illegal or undesirable quality.
examples: The alleged thief was arrested.
The alleged crime took place last night.

words.meaning: Loyalty or commitment of a subordinate to a superior or of an individual to a group or cause.
examples: They swore allegiance to the king.
His allegiance is to his family.

words.meaning: To make (suffering, deficiency, or a problem) less severe.
examples: The medicine is designed to alleviate pain.
Measures have been taken to alleviate poverty.

words.meaning: A metal made by combining two or more metallic elements, especially to give greater strength or resistance to corrosion.
examples: Bronze is an alloy of copper and tin.
The alloy is used in the construction of aircraft.

words.meaning: To suggest or call attention to indirectly; hint at.
examples: She alluded to the problem but didn't go into detail.
He alluded to his past failures.

words.meaning: The quality of being powerfully and mysteriously attractive or fascinating.
examples: The allure of the city is its vibrant nightlife.
She could not resist the allure of the forbidden fruit.

words.meaning: An expression designed to call something to mind without mentioning it explicitly; an indirect or passing reference.
examples: The poem is full of classical allusions.
He made a brief allusion to his recent troubles.

words.meaning: (of a remark or reference) working by suggestion rather than explicit mention.
examples: Her speech was allusive and full of hidden meanings.
He has an allusive style of writing.

words.meaning: A state formally cooperating with another for a military or other purpose.
examples: The United States is a close ally of the United Kingdom.
They were allies in the fight against a common enemy.

words.meaning: Not friendly or forthcoming; cool and distant.
examples: He seemed aloof and uninterested.
She remained aloof from the others.
